journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Effects of muscle-equivalent forces on the biomechanical behavior of proximal femur fracture models: a pilot study on artificial bones

contrib-group.aff: Department of Orthopaedics and Traumatology, Albert-Ludwigs-University Freiburg, Germany

fn.p: This paper was included as part of this extended section of the Lower Limb Musculoskeletal Modelling Special Issue.

author-notes.corresp: Lukas Konstantinidis, Department of Orthopaedics and Traumatology, Albert-Ludwigs-University Freiburg, Hugstetter Strasse 55, Freiburg 79106, Germany. Email: lukas.konstantinidis@uniklinik-freiburg.de

article-meta.issue-title: Includes a special section on musculoskeletal modelling of the lower limb

sec.title: Introduction:
sec.p: There has been extensive analysis of the influence of muscle forces and their effects on the biomechanical behavior of the proximal femur. Nevertheless, these forces have only been taken into account in a handful of biomechanical studies in the field of traumatology. The aim of this study was to analyze the biomechanical behavior of two typical fracture models of the proximal femur based on muscle-equivalent forces.

sec.title: Method:
sec.p: Plate osteosynthesis was performed on two groups of artificial femora to stabilize either a trochanteric osteotomy (n = 5) or a femur shaft osteotomy (n = 5). After fixation axial loading was applied to the constructs first without muscle-equivalent forces and then with the addition of these forces (abductor groups and vastus lateralis). Displacement at the osteotomy site and the stiffness of the whole construct were measured during loading.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Comparison of the two loading modes revealed no significant differences for displacement or stiffness for the trochanteric fractures. For the femur shaft fractures, a significant difference was found for displacement (p = 0.023) and stiffness (p = 0.003) with or without muscle-equivalent forces.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: The loading protocol for implant testing on femur shaft fractures should include muscle-equivalent forces. For trochanteric fractures, consideration of muscle forces is not entirely necessary since they will have little effect on the results, for example, when comparing implants.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The importance of the abductors and the iliotibial tract in the loading behavior of the femur was described by Pauwels et al.1 and was later analyzed in many studies.2 In the meantime, several muscle groups of the femur and the hip joint have been investigated by means of computer simulation3–6 and experimental methods.7 Reliable, standardized, established models exist for mechanical testing of hip prostheses, including mechanical simulation of the muscles of the proximal femur, and these can be integrated into pre-clinical testing.8 In research and implant testing in the field of trauma surgery muscle forces have been ignored in the majority of studies. It is only in a small number of current biomechanical test series9–11 that the muscle forces, equivalent to those of the proximal femur, have been taken into account, whereby the forces applied are not usually standardized or controlled. The objective of this pilot study was to investigate the behavior of two typical osteosyntheses in the region of the femur in response to simulation of two specific muscle groups in the context of a well established test set-up.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: An AO type 31A-2.3 pertrochanteric osteotomy (Group A, n = 5) or an AO type 32A-3 femur shaft osteotomy (Group B, n = 5) was created on a total of 10 biomechanically validated left side artificial bones (Composite Femur, 4th generation, Sawbone®, Malmö, Sweden).12 The trochanteric fracture (Group A) on the model was created by standardization of an unstable pertrochanteric fracture, as described in the work by Bonnaire et al.,9 with a defect zone extending 10 mm into the calcar. In the femur shaft model (Group B) a 10 mm transverse defect zone was created at a standardized distance from the lesser trochanter. The fracture was followed in both groups by implantation of a plate fixator (less invasive stabilisation system-LISS-DF in “reversed LISS” technique;13,14 Synthes, Bettlach, Switzerland). Self-cutting, fixed-angle screws were inserted into all the proximal plate holes except for positions B and C (according to the official designations given in the OR manual – Figure 1). The screws in positions A and G were inserted bicortically as far as the calcar. In the region of the plate shaft, bicortical self-cutting, fixed-angle screws were inserted into positions 2, 4, 6 and 8 from proximal to distal (Figure 1). The distal 8 cm of the artificial femora were sawn off and the residual femur shaft was embedded to a depth of 5 cm in polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) (Technovit 3040, Heraeus Kulzer GmbH, Wehrheim, Germany).

caption.p: Left: Photograph of a construct in Group A (trochanteric fracture) with muscle simulation of the abductors (red arrow) and vastus lateralis (orange). The yellow arrow indicates the direction of the applied axial load. Right: Lateral view of the construct with the LISS DF Plate and numbering of the used screw holes. The antecurvation of the plate, which has been designed for die distal femur, equates the proximal antecurvation of femur.

sec.p: For testing, the constructs were fixed in the universal testing device (UTS 20/testControl®, UTS Systems, Ulm, Germany. Software: TestXpert® II, Zwick, Ulm, Germany). On the frontal plane, bones were fixed with 13° adduction, on the sagittal plane there was no angulation of the constructs. First, all 10 constructs were subjected to both static and dynamic axial loading up to 1000 N (Group A) and up to 500 N (Group B) with a force-controlled displacement of 20 N/s. Each loading cycle was repeated five times for each construct. Partial body weight loading of 300 N – as is prescribed during the rehabilitation period following fracture treatment – leads to a 1000 N load on the femoral head.15 This value of 1000 N has generally been applied in the majority of biomechanical test series on similar implants.16,17 For the femur shaft fracture model the load was reduced to 500 N since pilot studies had shown that a load of 1000 N would exceed the “yield point“ of the construct and cause plastic deformation.

Following the load series, cables were mounted (Figure 1) to simulate the effects of two important muscle groups. The point, direction and magnitude of load was defined with reference to current literature18,19 (load type “Duda 5”), whereby the type of muscle load was simplified and reduced for the model. As a result, the simulated force for the group of abductors was 350/175 N (Groups A/B) in a direction of 33° towards proximal, acting towards the femoral axis in the frontal plane. In the sagittal plane the force was neutral (0°) to the mechanical axis of the femur. Vastus lateralis was simulated at a force of 350/175 N towards distal in the frontal plane parallel to the femoral axis and directed at 10° anterior in the sagittal plane. The cables were mounted so that the afore-mentioned forces coincided with a maximal axial load of 1000 N or 500 N. Tensile forces were monitored by means of digital strain gauges (force gauge PCE-FM 1000, PCE Group, Meschede, Germany).

Force transfer from the universal testing device to the femoral head was achieved via a coupling system that permitted free rotation and low friction displacement in all planes. To achieve force transmission across the whole of the central region of the femoral head, force transfer from the coupling system to the femoral head was conducted by means of a PMMA template custom-made for each specimen.
The biomechanical behavior of the constructs was recorded by two independent measuring systems.

list-item.p: The deformation of the whole construct was measured using the displacement of the test machine crosshead/actuator and used to calculate the structural stiffness as the gradient of the force–displacement curve.

The displacement at the medial fracture gap and, consequently, the displacement of the proximal fragment in relation to the femur shaft was mapped three-dimensionally based on the coordinate system (transversal, sagittal and frontal) as described by Bergmann et al.15 and supported by a validated20–22 ultrasound based system (CMS 20, Zebris® Medical, Isny, Germany) at a measurement accuracy of 0.1 mm. To ensure precise definition of the displacement in all three spatial axes, the magnitude of the resultant deformation vector c was calculated using the formula
c =
x 2
+
y 2
+
z 2
, where x, y, and z represent displacement in the frontal, sagittal and transversal planes.

sec.p: SPSS (SPSS Inc. Chicago, Illinois) release 15 was used for statistical analysis. The data was normally distributed as assessed by the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test so that a comparison of the paired series using a student’s t-Test could be carried out. Statistical significance was set at a threshold of p < 0.05.

sec.title: Group A (trochanteric fractures)
sec.p: In summary, no significant differences were found between the constructs with or without muscle-equivalent forces in terms of construct stiffness (412 versus 475 N/mm; p = 0.176; t-Test) or displacement at the osteotomy gap (resultant displacement vector 3.1 versus 3.5 mm; p = 0.24; t-Test) (Figure 2). None of the specimens were affected by implant failure or plastic deformation of the constructs/plates.

caption.p: Displacement at the osteotomy site and stiffness of the constructs with trochanteric osteotomy. The difference between the two groups was not significant.

sec.title: Group B (femur shaft fractures)
sec.p: In contrast to Group A, significant differences were found for the femur shaft fractures (Group B) in terms of stiffness (216 versus 285 N/mm; p = 0.003; t-Test) and displacement (resultant displacement vector 2.2 versus 1.1 mm; p = 0.023; t-Test). The constructs tested by application of forces equivalent to those of the hip abductors and vastus lateralis showed greater stiffness, and displacement at the osteotomy site was significantly lower (Figure 3). As in Group A none of the implants failed.

caption.p: Displacement at the osteotomy site and stiffness of the constructs with femur shaft osteotomy. The difference between the two groups was significant for both parameters.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In the present study, using a relatively straightforward experimental set-up, it was possible to show that muscle-equivalent forces influence the mechanical behavior of specific fracture types. In the case of trochanteric fracture, no significant differences in fracture displacement with or without these forces was found. This result is contrary to current mathematical calculations,18 whereby the current study was based on an osteosynthesis model in a purely experimental set-up. In the case of femur shaft fractures, mechanical behavior of the constructs under the influence of relevant muscle-equivalent tensile forces was far more stable. In both groups – trochanteric and shaft fractures – there was a high variability of stiffness and displacement among specimens of the same group despite the use of Sawbones, which are accepted to have a high reproducibility. That is a result of many factors influencing stiffness, such as osteosynthesis quality and muscle simulation.

Despite current attempts to simulate muscle action at the proximal femur as realistically as possible, successes have only been recorded so far for the development of well refined models based on FE-analysis. A complete, or almost complete, in vitro simulation on human specimens has not yet been conducted because of the many methodological challenges. The current study has several limitations so that the results reported here can only represent a point of departure for further research in the area of feasible simulation techniques. First, in comparison to the computer analyses mentioned above,18,19 our “muscle” approach does not correspond to an exactly calculated point. Even in comparison to the in vivo situation involving a complex interplay of muscle actions, the mathematically calculated muscle forces differ from those applied in our study based on selective or localized force application. A further limitation of the set-up is the pretensioning of the cables with the consequence that the relevant forces can only be monitored at maximum load. Graduated tensioning of the cables in relation to the load on the femoral head or the resultant vector, as would be calculated in the gait cycle, for example, was not possible for methodological reasons and may have influenced the mechanical properties of the constructs. In addition, only two muscle groups were simulated in this pilot study and more or less only in one plane, which does not mimic the complexity of the in vivo situation.

Despite these limitations, and based on the results presented here, the following statements can be made with regard to this straightforward test set-up. The application of muscle-equivalent forces cannot be recommended for testing trochanteric fractures because they will have little effect on the results, for example, when comparing implants. Furthermore, their simulation introduces an additional force into the model that is hard to control and that diminishes the reproducibility and standardization of an otherwise simple test set-up. In contrast, it seems logical to establish a standardized muscle simulation system for testing femur shaft fractures, since muscle action has a massive effect on the mechanical properties of the diaphyseal femur.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
